head.title: Neutrino decay and the thermochemical equilibrium of the interstellar medium

meta.name: keywords
meta.content: ISM: general – ISM: clouds – stars: formation – elementary particles

article.h1: Neutrino decay and the thermochemical equilibrium of the interstellar medium

span.span: 1Departamento de Física, Facultad Experimental de Ciencias, Universidad del Zulia, Maracaibo, Venezuela 12Centro de Astrofísica Teórica, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de los Andes, Mérida, Venezuela2
1Departamento de Física, Facultad Experimental de Ciencias, Universidad del Zulia, Maracaibo, Venezuela 1 nestor@orion.ciens.luz.ve

article.div: Key Words.:ISM: general – ISM: clouds – stars: formation – elementary particles

div.p: The diffuse interstellar medium (ISM) is observed to be inhomogeneous with cold (T≲102less-than-or-similar-to𝑇superscript102italic-T RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\la 10^{2} K) clouds embedded in a warmer (T∼104similar-to𝑇superscript104italic-T RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT\sim 10^{4} K) intercloud gas (see, for example, the review of Kulkarni & Heiles 1988). The theoretical explanation for this structure was provided by Field et al. (1969) who showed that two thermally stable phases can coexist in pressure equilibrium over a limited range of pressures, close to those observed in the ISM. Since the two-phase model of Field et al. (1969), the thermal and ionization equilibrium of the ISM and its stability have been studied by many authors including different heating and ionizing processes (Black 1987; Kulkarni & Heiles 1988). The response of the ISM to variations in physical processes and parameters are of interest both to a better understanding of the ISM behavior and because of its central role in star formation and galaxy evolution models. Effects on the ISM equilibrium of variations in, for example, X-ray and far UV radiation fields, cosmic ray ionization and metal abundance have been studied by several authors (Shull & Woods 1985; Parravano 1987; Wolfire et al. 1995; Parravano & Pech 1997). In this work, we are interested in a particular process: the flux of ionizing photons coming from the radiative decay of neutrinos (Sciama 1990). Notwithstanding this is a speculative theory, Sciama has argued in a set of papers (Sciama 1993, 1995, 1997a, 1997b, 1998) that it can explain the widespread ionization far from the galactic disk and many other observational results. The simplification in Sciama’s work is to assume a temperature of ∼104similar-toabsentsuperscript104RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 10^{4} K without explicitly solving the thermal equilibrium. The former was made by Dettmar & Schulz (1992) who showed that heat input associated with neutrino decay is too small to account for the observed ISM temperature. However, their conclusion that neutrino decay cannot be a dominant source of ionization could be mistaken, as was pointed out by Sciama (1993), because they neglected the existence of other known heating mechanisms. Our goal here is to analize, in a more complete and self-consistent way, the effect of ionization due to neutrino decay on the thermochemical equilibrium of the ISM.

In Sect. 2 we discuss the physical processes included in this work and provide the basic equations. Sect. 3 is dedicated to a discussion of the results, and the main conclusions are summarized in Sect. 4.

In order to analize the effect of neutrino decay photons on the thermochemical equilibrium, a simple model for the ISM is used. The included cooling mechanisms are: a) cooling by collisions of electrons with C+FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{+}, Si+FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{+}, Fe+FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{+}, O+FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{+}, S+FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{+} and N (ΛesubscriptΛ𝑒Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Lambda_{e}); b) cooling by collisions of neutral hydrogen with Si+FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{+}, Fe+FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{+} and C+FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{+} (ΛHsubscriptΛ𝐻Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Lambda_{H}); and c) cooling due to Ly-α𝛼italic-alpha\alpha excitation by electrons (ΛL⁢ysubscriptΛ𝐿𝑦Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Lambda_{Ly}). All the cooling rates and the relative abundances were taken from Dalgarno & McCray (1972). We consider the following heating mechanisms:
a) Interaction of cosmic ray with hydrogen atoms and electrons:

ergs cm POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p:
where n=n⁢(HI)+n⁢(HII)𝑛𝑛HI𝑛HIIitalic-n RELOP:equals italic-n OPEN:( HI CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-n OPEN:( HII CLOSE:)n=n({\rm HI})+n({\rm HII}) is the total number density of hydrogen, nesubscript𝑛𝑒italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{e} is the number density of electrons and χ=n⁢(HII)/n𝜒𝑛HII𝑛italic-chi RELOP:equals italic-n OPEN:( HII CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-n\chi=n({\rm HII})/n is the ionization degree of hydrogen. The number of secondary ionizations (ΦΦPhi\Phi) was taken from Dalgarno & McCray (1972), and the primary ionization rate is assumed to be ζc⁢r=10-17⁢s-1subscript𝜁𝑐𝑟superscript1017superscripts1italic-zeta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:17 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\zeta_{cr}=10^{-17}\ {\rm s^{-1}} (Spitzer 1978; Black et al. 1990; Webber 1998).
b) Heating by H2subscriptH2H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\rm H}_{2} formation on dust grains (Spitzer 1978):

div.p: c) Photoelectric heating from small grains and PAHs (Bakes & Tielens 1994):

div.p: where the heating efficiency (ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon) is given by

div.p: and Gosubscript𝐺𝑜italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:endG_{o} is the far UV field normalized to its solar neighborhood value.
We only consider ionization/recombination for hydrogen. The recombination rate is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-X POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-chi italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:) s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where α⁢(T)𝛼𝑇italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)\alpha(T) is the recombination coefficient to all states except the ground one, and it was taken from Spitzer (1978). The rate of ionization by cosmic rays is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-zeta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-phi CLOSE:) OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-chi CLOSE:) s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: We also use the simple analytic fits provided by Wolfire et al. (1995) to estimate the ionization (XX⁢R-superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑋𝑅italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-X italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{XR}^{-}) and heating (ΓX⁢RsubscriptΓ𝑋𝑅Gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-X italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Gamma_{XR}) due to the soft X-ray background as functions of the column density (Nwsubscript𝑁𝑤italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{w}) and the electron fraction (ne/nsubscript𝑛𝑒𝑛italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-nn_{e}/n). In this work we adopt Nw=1019⁢cm-2subscript𝑁𝑤superscript1019superscriptcm2italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:19 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end cm POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{w}=10^{19}{\rm cm^{-2}}.
In addition to the above sources of ionization, we also consider the photons produced by neutrino decay. The ionization due to this mechanism can be written in the form (Sciama 1990):

semantics.annotation: italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-sigma OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-chi CLOSE:) s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: An interesting consequence has to be noted: neutrino beams from neighboring regions may induce the condensation of cold clouds stimulating the formation of stars. The importance of star formation triggered by previously formed stars has been recognized by many authors (see the review of Elmegreen 1992). Triggering mechanisms are usually related to compression of the ISM by shock waves from close supernovas, because the transition warm gas →→ARROW:rightarrow\rightarrow cold gas is promoted if the ISM pressure rises over Pm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑎𝑥italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP_{max}. Although this kind of mechanism can act only over short distances (compared with the Galaxy size) it can propagate over large scales, and the idea of self-propagated star formation has been used to study the formation of spatial patterns in galactic disks (Mueller & Arnett 1976; Gerola & Seiden 1978; Seiden & Gerola 1979; Schulman & Seiden 1990; Jungwiert & Palous 1994). However, the phase transition warm gas →→ARROW:rightarrow\rightarrow cold clouds can be also obtained by decreasing Pm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑎𝑥italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP_{max} under P𝑃italic-PP (assumed constant) if the local flux of decaying neutrinos increases due, for example, to an increase in the supernova explosion rate. This triggering mechanism depends on the propagation of neutrinos, and therefore can act over large distances in short time intervals. On the other hand, star formation can also inhibit in different ways the warm gas condensation self-regulating the star formation process inclusively over large distances (Cox 1983; Franco & Shore 1984; Struck-Marcell & Scalo 1987; Parravano 1988, 1989). It has been shown that star formation inhibition (rather than stimulation) can also contribute to the formation and maintenance of spatial patterns in galaxies (Freedman & Madore 1984; Chappell & Scalo 1997). Stimulation and inhibition mechanisms of star formation must be acting simultaneously in the Galaxy, but it is not clear yet what spatial scales are important for each one. The effect of non-local star formation stimulation on the formation of spiral patterns in galaxies should be analysed in future models.

section.div: Acknowledgements. This work has been partially supported by CONDES of Universidad del Zulia. The authors are very grateful to an anonymous referee for several helpful suggestions, and to Cesar Mendoza for his assistance in the manuscript preparation.

Wolfire M.G., Hollenbach D., McKee C.F., Tielens A.G.G.M., Bakes E.L.O., 1995, ApJ 443, 152.
